details.title: Reliability Analysis on the <formula formulatype="inline"> <tex>$\delta$</tex></formula>-Shock Model of Complex Systems
details.standardTitle: Reliability Analysis on the <formula formulatype="inline"> <tex>$\delta$</tex></formula>-Shock Model of Complex Systems

p: Zehui Li is a full professor of Probability and Statistics at the School of Mathematics and Statistics at Lanzhou University, and is also the director of the Institute of Mathematical Statistics & Reliability Theory, also at Lanzhou University. She has published in journals such as IEEE Transactions on Reliability, the Journal of Statistical Planning and Inference, Stat. & Prob. Letters, International J. of Reliability, Quality and Safety Engineering, Far east J. Theo. Stat., Chinese J. of Appl. Prob. and Stat., Acta. Math. Appl. Sinica, and Journal of Lanzhou University. Her research interests include counting processes and their applications, reliability, survival analysis, risk theory, and asymptotic theory.

authors.affiliation: Sch. of Math. & Stat., Lanzhou Univ.
authors.name: Zehui Li

p: Peng Zhao is a PhD student at the School of Mathematics and Statistics, Lanzhou University. His research interests include aging properties, stochastic order, $k$-out-of-$n$ structures, and shock models.

authors.affiliation: Sch. of Math. & Stat., Lanzhou Univ.
authors.name: Peng Zhao

details.abstract: We investigate the delta-shock model of complex systems consisting of n i.i.d. components. We first obtain a general lifetime distribution for the delta-shock model of a general complex system by reducing the system to a linear combination of parallel systems. We then consider coherent system structures including series, parallel, and k-out-of-n, then derive some useful results including reliability bounds, bounds on the mean lifetime, limiting distributions, and Laplace-Stieltes transforms

links.abstract: We review the principal progress of shock models during the last three decades. Our new model, the delta-shock model, and its latest developments are also introduced. Furthermore, for adapting shock models to a wider reliability field, we put forward a generalized framework for studying shock models, based on cluster point processes with cluster marks. In addition, we provide a noteworthy case under this framework as a concrete example in reliability with an insurance background, and give the as...

context.text: [1] introduced the latest developments of the single component \$\delta\$-shock model.

references.text: J. M. Bai, Z. H. Li, X. B. Kong, "Generalized shock models based on a cluster point process", IEEE Trans. Reliability, vol. 55, pp. 542-550, 2006.

context.text: For more details, we refer to Esary et al. [5], Barlow & Proschan [2], Gaver [20], and Ross [18].
Firstly, we present a useful lemma due to Balow & Proschan [2].
Before proceeding to state our main results, we first present some definitions & lemmas which can be found in Barlow & Proschan [2].

links.abstract: This paper studies a geometric-process maintenance-model for a deteriorating system under a random environment. Assume that the number of random shocks, up to time t, produced by the random environment forms a counting process. Whenever a random shock arrives, the system operating time is reduced. The successive reductions in the system operating time are statistically independent and identically distributed random variables. Assume that the consecutive repair times of the system after failures,...

[13] obtained the explicit distribution, the moment, NBU/NWU properties of the system lifetime, and its asymptotic behavior as \$\delta\rightarrow0\$.
[13], we shall also study two \$\delta\$-shock models for these complex systems.

context.text: A new case, called the run shock model, defined by Mallor & Omey [16], means a system works until \$k\$ consecutive shocks occur with their magnitude entering into the critical region, where \$k\geq 1\$.

context.text: Petakos & Tsapelas [17] studied several properties of a complex system.
Putting our models together with the main results in Pekakos & Tsapelas [17], we can obtain the following theorem.
The coefficient \$g(n,m)\$ satisfies We will not give the proofs for Theorem 2.1 & Lemma 2.2 in the Appendix because they are completely similar to those in Petakos & Tsapelas [17].

Skoulakis [20] studied general complex systems subject to shocks generated by a renewal point process; and derived closed expressions for the Laplace-Stieltjes transform, the expectations, and the density of the time to system failure.

context.text: Shanthikumar & Sumita [21] extended Poisson shock to general shock, and studied such a shock model in which a system fails when the shock magnitude of a single shock outstrips a given positive value.

renewal sequences

context.text: In maintenance problems, an optimal replacement policy of the repairable \$\delta\$-shock system is obtained by Wang & Zhang [23], and Tang & Lam [22] described the system failure by the positive quantity \$\delta\$, which represents the inter-arrival time of a deterioration system.
